characters: AT THE BACK OF THE HALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloomy, last light. From out of the shadows comes A DOG. A dog of war. Big, mangy, muscular, scary. As he moves down the alley, the way becomes increasingly choked with fallen structures. and signs of tumult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH THE DOG as he comes onto a battlefield. The hellish scene is REVEALED TO US SLOWLY --

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: as the Dog traverses a landscape of -- BODIES, frozen in contorted death poses. This was furious, hand-to-hand fighting between human SOLDIERS and nightmare CREATURES, their corpses now in piles to the horizon. The Dog climbs a mound of casualties. At the top, the Dog looks back across the battlefield. The Dog's eyes are sad, his expression weary and disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entrance is patrolled by a dozen PALACE GUARDS. They don't see the Dog pad silently to a fissure in the palace wall and disappear inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloodied and battered, the King's GENERALS are disagreeing loudly about strategy. A loud BANGING sound pierces the hubbub, and the officers quiet, turning to -- KING ACRISIUS, a striking man in his prime, his handsome face marked by one crooked scar on his jaw. He commands the room --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we end the debate about tactics... and begin to plan for victory.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK OF THE HALL
dialogues.text: The Dog stares at the King. Then slips away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unseen by exhausted Guards, the Dog bounds up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dog approaches a doorway; stops to watch from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dim bedchamber, the SILHOUETTE of QUEEN DANAE as a LADY-IN-WAITING removes her gown, revealing the Queen's perfect body as she slips into bed. The Lady-in-Waiting leaves. The Dog's eyes. He moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH the Dog's legs as they MORPH INTO HUMAN LEGS. The CAMERA RISES BEHIND a towering male figure, who roughly pulls a curtain aside. In the bed, the Queen is startled, then pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My King! Has the strategy been set so quickly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The looming figure looks exactly like King Acrisius, including the distinctive scar. He regards her hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to your Queen, my King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real King Acrisius wearily climbs the stairs with AIDES and Guards. Suddenly, the King stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wall above is the huge shadow of a four-legged creature -- and now it appears: The Dog stops at the top of the stairs and regards the men without fear -- its eyes blaze with a God's power. Even Acrisius, who fears nothing, steps back. The others raise their weapons. The Dog comes down the steps, eyes upon them, and passes close by. No one dare move. The Dog disappears into the shadows below.

dialogues.speaker: HARDENED COUNTENANCE
dialogues.text: staring at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen Danae, PREGNANT NOW, and weeping. Her arms are bound. A ROYAL ENTOURAGE is gathered. The women weep, the men agonize. Palace Guards lift the Queen into a chest and chain it closed. On the King's signal, the Guards carry the chest to the edge and drop it into the rough sea. We HEAR a SCREAM from within. Some members of the Royal Entourage look with scorn at their King, outraged by this double murder. Acrisius registers their disapproving looks and angrily turns to leave the promontory. WE SEE in his face what the others do not -- shame and doubt. IN THE WATER BELOW, the chest rights itself and rides out on the tide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two HORSEMEN gallop in the moonlight. The first Rider sways in the saddle and falls from his mount. He staggers to his feet, a skin of ale in his hands. It is King Acrisius, very drunk. The second Rider, the King's STEWARD, dismounts to give aid, though he's also drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own subjects condemn me! They dare judge me? And what emboldens this treachery?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are mistaken, my King. None would risk your anger --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oblivious to him) It is Zeus who warps my kinadom!... Zeus the ungodly, Zeus the defiler... This talk sobers the Steward instantly; he looks about fearlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, speak not these things Acrisius spins on him, out of control --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cuckolds me in my castle, rapes my precious Queen! This is a low, conniving God... But I have bested him on this day and humbled the great Prime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Panos, who rivals Zeus on Olympos? Who does the Fearless One fear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, Your Highness -- Acrisius pulls a dagger and holds it to the Steward's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what the Priests say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified, halting) Tiamat... Tiamat, Queen of the Deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those who dare, whisper she covets Zeus' throne and schemes to achieve it, the ambitious Goddess of the Dark Oceans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Tiamat! And today I have honored her. The King whirls and staggers up the crest of the dune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've taken Zeus' whore and the bastard she grows in her belly and thrown them to Tiamat in her rough sea! (toward the moonlit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I honor Zeus' rival with all that was dear to me -- (falters, ashamed) -- and commit double murder in her honor... About to go to pieces, rage seizes him again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: so that Zeus will know I despise and disdain him and spit on his foul name! The Steward shrinks from this blasphemy, eyes darting in fear. ON THE CREST the King is silhouetted in the moonlight, arms raised defiantly toward the heavens, when suddenly - -- his figure is seized by some violent force, shaking his being. A HORRIBLE SOUND and THE KING'S BODY GROWS LARGER AS IT DISTORTS IN MISSHAPEN DISFIGUREMENT. And thus, KING ACRISIUS BECOMES... KALIBOS! The Steward SEES what we now cannot. An INHUMAN ROAR and the shadow of this new being falls upon the Steward. He SCREAMS, but it's too late -- the huge CREATURE grabs him by the neck and LIFTS HIM OUT OF FRAME. From the empty, moonlit dunes, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen Danae's coffin/chest tossing in the rough water. Through the ROAR of the waves, we HEAR a BABY CRY. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LITTLE BOY leads a blind OLD MAN along a road. Abruptly, the Old Man halts. Puzzled, the Boy scans ahead, SEES -- -- a SPRAY OF DUST, moving fast, behind a blurred BLACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in an instant, the apparition blows past them -- wind and dust whip at them. In awe and fear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoth the Quick... (sensing the boy's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Messenger of the Gods. Bound for Olympos. The rushing Black Form crosses a field, leaving a violent wave in the long grass and suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE ARE IN THAT RUSHING POV: the landscape is just a blur. But up ahead is a mountain: OLYMPOS. WE ZOOM UP TO the summit -- -- INTO the clouds above the peak. THROUGH the mist -- villas, classical facades: THE ABODE OF THE GODS. The polished stone of the grandest villa reflects THOTH'S dark form touching down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOTH THE QUICK enters the wide courtyard, his cape billowing. He strides past the reflecting pool in the center of the courtyard, gravely acknowledging -- -- each of the TEN FIGURES seated around the perimeter... THE OLYMPIANS. APOLLO is here, and bronze-helmeted ATHENA; APHRODITE and muscular VULCAN -- we are dazzled and lose count. Thoth bows deeply before the throne of ZEUS, majestic, bearded, awe-inspiring. An EAGLE is perched on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rumbles, like

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have debated, we have voted, and it is decided. We offer the Humans peace. Thoth, you will take them the terms of a treaty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A treaty! Zeus and his eagle turn their heads. The God's eyes are familiar -- the blazing orbs we saw in The Dog. In the shadowed corner of the atrium stand TWO MORE Olympians: SET THE VOID, whose countenance is death made visible, and -- -- TIAMAT, QUEEN OF THE DEEP, the only God fearless enough to challenge Zeus' rule --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't negotiate with them! We dictate to them. Their place is to beg. They have forgotten their role and have denied us the sustenance of their prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our mercy will give them reason to be grateful. They will bow down and whisper our names with more passion than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will bow down when we snap their backs! Mercy? We are Gods! Some of us remember that and are not afraid -- Zeus has had enough: furious ARCS OF LIGHTNING jump to the walls, the eagle beats its wings in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence! Or learn what it is to be afraid! The debate is over, the votes cast... Zeus points to a golden tray; it bears TEN chips of alabaster versus TWO shards of obsidian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We guarantee an armistice, we shield the bridegroom and the Joppan royal family. (turning again on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we do not interfere in their actions. We leave them undisturbed unless-invoked by name to enter their affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if they refuse our terms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have suffered terrible losses. They will not pass up a chance for peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Tiamat and Set now. Tiamat regards Zeus' throne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your rightful place to take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon enough, Set. Zeus has grown weaker than I knew. Set gestures at the white chips on the tray as he picks up the two black shards representing their votes. He hands one to Tiamat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So have they all. They no longer see clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're beginning to think like Men. But you and I shall not. Set agrees, his eyes searching her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will manage these thick-witted Humans to our own ends. (off his look) Yes, we will be bound by great Zeus' rules... until their fragile membranes tear. We dare not interfere with these insects...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: but we may be invited to                                  intervene. Tiamat flicks the obsidian into the reflecting pool -- the whole pool darkens and choppy waves crash over the sides... a tiny tempest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: someone. impulsive and vain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The emissary approaches. Take your time in your responses, debate nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've received ambassadors before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not cowed. If these arrogant Gods are so powerful, why are they the ones seeking a truce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only recommend you take care with the tone of the conversation. A truce would benefit all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my palace, I decide how the discourse proceeds, not some messenger sent on errands by Zeus.

dialogues.speaker: THOTH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You are correct, Your Highness, I do the bidding of Zeus... To their astonishment, the emissary is already in the Throne Room, behind them. Startled, they turn to see Thoth the Quick, Messenger of the Gods, float forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as do all Gods... and all men. Thoth removes his hood, revealing his crystal skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edge) King Kepheus, as humble messenger of Zeus, I've come to talk of peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoth the Quick, I am Amoun, the King's Magi Strategos. We welcome you with humility, honored by your visit from the realm of the Gods. The King shoots Amoun a look, but he is still shaken by Thoth's sudden appearance. Cassiopeia tries to recover her composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a reasonable man. Everyone wishes for the conflict to cease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeus above all. He has so long desired the tragedy end, he made a plan that began twenty-five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five years! How is that possible? Amoun winces at her tone. Thoth sends a scary glance her way. Icy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauteous Queen, let Thoth limn for you the forethought and wisdom of Zeus, God of Gods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The market, now quiet, tries to return to normalcy. But the crowd watches the Basilica, worried by the God's presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kepheus and Cassiopeia sit stunned. Amoun watches without surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A treaty marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a daughter of age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromeda!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely Zeus does not ask a mortal father to give his daughter to a God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Such a union would be unclean. Years ago Zeus created a scion of mixed blood. Half-man, half-God. Bred for just this union. That is how important Zeus considers this truce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my only daughter to marry a demigod, not of this earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prince, of both Olympian and Human royalty. A chosen one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeus has given his son to the cause of peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have heard of no such demigod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, if I may -- the young man does exist. He lives in a small fishing village on the isle of                          Seriphos. Kepheus turns, surprised at Amoun's foreknowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew about this and said nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just which king do you serve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Queen, I serve only the great order of things. I was the boy's tutor years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How haughty this boy must be, who                       knows he is half-God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows nothing and believes himself an ordinary man. He has never left his village. He can be                       overconfident, but it is from                           inexperience, not arrogance.                            Repheus and Cassiopeia exchange wary looks. Sharply

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What assurance do we have that our                      daughter will be safe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have my word, as Ambassador of the Gods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With our daughter's future at stake, we do not bestow trust easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If any harm should come to her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amoun reacts, but it is too late -- Thoth has been

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the WALLS GROAN, compressing with an AWFUL SHUDDER. The room TILTS. Kepheus and the Queen grab for a solid handhold, frightened. The golden marbles on a tabletop roll from their pits and pile up in defiance of gravity. Wine goblets tilt toward Thoth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princessa shall not be harmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently, to the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... of course your word is unquestioned here. Thoth's demeanor changes. The marbles spill off the table, rolling across the floor to Kepheus' feet. TILT UP TO his intimidated face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the lucky young suitor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly blue, sunlight shafting from the surface. A GREAT WHITE SHARK appears, ensnared in a fisherman's net. Panicked, the shark is diving as fast as it can. As the net passes we see -- ANTEROS, a hapless young fisherman, his legs entangled in the net, desperately trying to hold his breath. When they have disappeared, we see a FIGURE appear through the blue in pursuit. As he passes, we get our first look

dialogues.speaker: PERSEUS,
dialogues.text: a knife in his teeth. He swims with the power and grace of a porpoise -- beyond the ability of any normal man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shark thrashes about, jaws snapping close to Anteros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus swims INTO VIEW and uses his knife to cut the net near the shark's snout. The shark tries to swim through the hole, but instead drags the net upwards. Perseus hangs on. One more slice and the shark zooms out of the net, bumping the young hero as it swims away. Perseus pulls Anteros toward the surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CREW of FISHERMEN wait desperately at the rail. SPYROS, the oldest and toughest, watches in agony. Perseus breaks the surface, gasping, his lifeless friend in his arms. Five crewmen dive in to help, but Perseus is mad with despair. They have to pull him away. Spyros watches sadly. But also, relieved to see the one survivor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spyros makes his way to the bow, where Perseus sits alone, downcast, in pain. Spyros watches in silence. Then, gruffly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your grieving does Anteros no good. It comforts only you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was careless with the net. Perseus gives him a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's his fault. Not mine, not fate, not the Gods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gods delude themselves about their power and watch in envy while we act. We make our own history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaks down, crying) Now my history is I let my friend die in my arms. I made it back, why couldn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you do, no other man can do. Have you not noticed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what purpose? I failed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Purpose! Looking for purpose is what ensnares men in the superstition of the Gods, as surely as your friend was caught in that net. And all the searching leads down to the same place. The trawler is approaching its home island, Seriphos. Perseus looks off at the rocky coast. Collects himself,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that my abilities are greater than other men's. But they were not enough to save him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are still a man, confined by man's limits. You are just as likely to fail as succeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that greater than other men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordinary men fail most of the time. The trawler rounds a point on the island. Perseus spies a beautiful girl on the cliff. A closer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huntress; a pagan leather bandeau hugs her lithe figure. Flowers in her golden hair -- wilted dahlias. Young yet ancient. THE WILTING GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches Perseus intently as the boat passes. He turns to see if Spyros or his friends have seen her, but no one has. When he looks back, she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus sits looking sadly at the sea that killed his friend. TEKLA, from the modest stone dwelling. She sees his mood and     touches his arm gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother wants you to come in for supper. (as he is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus, why are you so sad? This breaks his spell. He looks at Tekla warmly, gets up and puts a reassuring arm around her shoulders as they head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus eats with his adoptive family: Spyros, his wife MARMARA, and Tekla. Spyros is patient and twinkly with his wife though he disagrees with her beliefs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother can explain. She believes everything has an explanation, even if we have to make it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of the reasons I love you, Marmara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me! Why is there war between Man and the Gods? Marmara and Tekla continue to bring out the food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the beginning of time, when Man was young, he prayed to the Gods. His belief in the Gods gave his life meaning. It was a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you consider superstition, fear and darkness good things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Man grew, as children do, and he turned away from the Gods. Be began to put his faith in other things. Perseus watches the debate with fiery eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learning, science... love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: self-determination! Those things that give Man dignity and independence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what of the Gods, who had protected and guided us so long? They must breathe our prayers to survive. They hunger for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as lions hunger for blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spyros!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father's mind is closed on these matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gods were desperate to claim our awe again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desperate... the Gods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, even the Gods. If they could not earn our faith with love, they would demand it with fear. Whatever was necessary to ensure              L their continued existence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marmara and the wide-eyed Tekla sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is how war broke out between Man and Gods. (turning to serve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now eat your dinner, which the Gods -- and your father -- have provided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Middle of the night. Perseus lies wide awake in his tiny space. He stares, thinking about his friend. Suddenly, a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus opens the door to the Wilting Girl. Her beauty electrifies him. She glows from within, but her color is oddly faded, washed-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... I saw you watching our boat at the cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was not the boat I was watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be of service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of service. I need you to come with me on a journey. Perseus gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now? (as she nods) It wouldn't take much persuading to get me to leave this village, but tonight is impossible. My family can't wake and find me gone. Where do you want me to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what I want. I am in the service of others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus can't get over her beauty, the dulcet sound of her voice. Even so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back in the morning and we can talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? Perseus doesn't notice the black widow spider scurry between her feet. Then a centipede, a scorpion. Then a swarm, racing toward him. He feels the first spider and looks down. The creatures climb his legs, biting. Weakening from the venom, he stumbles back into the table, loses his balance and falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wilting Girl standing placidly in the doorway watching him.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He blacks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white sail, swollen with wind, draws the small boat swiftly across the sea. The Wilting Girl, alone, sits quietly at the stern, effortlessly steering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE that she is also watching Perseus, who is sleeping in a makeshift bed in the bottom of the boat. Her eyes slowly travel over his bronzed, muscled frame. There are bite marks on his legs and arms, but they seem to be healing as we look at them. Perseus stirs and wakes, squinting up at the Wilting Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I been out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time? Only a few hours. The time before, almost a day. How was your rest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a dream. I fell into a dark pit. I thought I would never stop falling. But a beam of light formed a soft net, caught me and tossed me back. TheWilting Girl watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I came back up to the world, a beautiful woman appeared and spoke to me. But as she spoke she would sometimes disappear into the whiteness with a strange sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wilting Girl listens to his story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I could hear her, she spoke nonsense. She said that my father was a God and my mother a -- At that moment the blinding-white sail swings between them as she tacks, obscuring his view of her for a moment. The wind makes a LOUD SNAPPING SOUND in the cloth. Then she reappears, the sail on her other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he realizes she is his vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are special, Perseus. Your birth was ordained for this very purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am an ordinary man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever lie awake during a storm and listen to the thunder?

dialogues.speaker: WILTING GIRL
dialogues.text: And it sounds as though it matches the beating of your heart? He doesn't have to answer; it's written on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long can you hold your breath? Longer than the others? Are there times when you know you should feel pain, but you don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of that means anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at your arms, Perseus. Perseus watches the bites on his arm heal visibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good trick. You must be the demigod, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Chthonian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Chthonian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Earth Goddess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gods have a caste system just as men do. The Olympians are our nobility -- few but cosmic. The Chthonians are the peasants. Our abode is this earth, and we exist as long as men worship us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when none worship you? Sadness flickers through her extraordinary eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fade away. This touches Perseus deeply. His tone changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And demigods, where do they stand in your hierarchy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowhere. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If demigods rank so low, why do you need me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeus, God of Gods, has proposed a treaty to end the war. At the center is the marriage of a mortal with a demigod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeus himself has chosen you. A demigod may be less than a God, but he's more than a Man. One foot in Humanity, the other in Divinity. Your marriage will be a symbol of accord between our races.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a union could save millions of souls. Perseus is struck by that. He looks off across the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just who exactly am I supposed to marry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP: A hot embrace. In the blur of movement our first good look is at the GIRL, a beauty -- PRINCESSA

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMEDA,
dialogues.text: The BOY is AGENOR, a kitchen helper -- ripped and sexy. It's hard to tell who's the aggressor here. Gasping, Andromeda holds him at bay --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you can manhandle a Princess this way? (as he kisses her) As though she was hungry and needy as you, a mere servant? Another steamy kiss. In between liplocks, she whispers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: very mistaken... a woman of my station... never be attracted... They go at it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NIMBLE GIRL hurries past SERVANTS hanging laundry in the atrium. She's PESHET, handmaid to Princessa Andromeda. She has a feline quality -- eyes, grace, agility. She raps on the scullery door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess... Princess!

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMEDA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled from inside) The Princess is not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find another... Princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen approaches!

dialogues.speaker: ANDROMEDA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't care!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromeda! You'll care enough if you're caught! Remember last time... From inside we HEAR complaining, more kissing and moaning.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIOPEIA
dialogues.text: Peshet! Startled, Peshet spins to see the Queen approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the Princess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromeda freezes at her mother's voice, stops Agenor, finger to her lips. He ignores her, starts again. Andromeda does something below the frame that jolts him off. The girl can take care of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peshet faces the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she not in her chambers, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is not. You are expected to know her -- A SQUEAL and WHISPERING from the closet stops Cassiopeia. She throws a perturbed glance at the door. Peshet looks guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the Princess -- should you find her -- her father and I want to see her at once. She stalks away. Urgently, through the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess, it's the King as well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavish room. Cassiopeia and Kepheus sit in golden chairs, looking off. Andromeda ENTERS FRAME, furious. with conviction --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To please you, I would submit to such a marriage... except I would rather die; Please let me know you're serious about this perverse plan so I can make arrangements to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stomps out. Their gaze follows until she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will take more than half-a-God to handle her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be a great ruler one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus can't take his eyes off the Wilting Girl, who steers. She tries not to be self-conscious; she would blush were she not so pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking in the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should give some thought to your immediate future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, flirtatious) That's what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should take another look... She indicates the view behind him. Perseus turns, jaw dropping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breathtaking view of Joppa -- a city in two parts. At sea level, tangled hovels, boats, and docks crowd the working-class area -- the LOWER WHARF. Above, twisting stone stairs climb the cliffs to the ACROPOLIS with its gleaming villas, temples, statues, and colonnaded towers, hugging the precipice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wilting Girl leads Perseus through the city. He's never seen anything like it. He rubbernecks, awestruck as he passes a BLACKSMITH who takes a dragon skin from the coals and fashions armor by pounding the white-hot scales over a mold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the goods, armies, and culture of Man's dominion flow through this port. He who reigns in Joppa, rules the world. Amidst the exotic chaos, Perseus is struck by   the homeless refugees on the street and the ruins   of once- proud buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war has badly scarred this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the war you have the power to end.                He throws her an angry look, grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't joke about such things. I'd be useless before such a huge responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you would be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as you are now. They pass an evangelist                        (FANTASOS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- one true God is not Zeus but she called the Deep -- Tiamat! (quoting from his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Before the first dawn, the eyes of the Deep watched the earth.' (to the crowd) Bow down to the Goddess of Chaos or know despair, for Tiamat will rule the heavens and the earth. Perseus is mystified by this talk. He turns to Vidalia for explanation, but she seems disturbed by the preacher and does not return Perseus' gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus and Vidalia round a corner and see the regal Basilica. WORKMEN hang banners and decorations, preparing for a big event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they celebrating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassiopeia hurries down a corridor to the parlor. WE FOLLOW to find: Kepheus speaking sternly to Perseus, before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . before I am a king or a peacemaker, I am a father. Do you know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, Your Highness. I did not know my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well... it means I had no desire for my little girl's carefree springtime to be cut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cassiopeia,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she's preparing herself to make the best possible impression. Perseus suppresses a smile, amused by the royal couple. Kepheus paces with mounting impatience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and all so she could be thrust into a momentous conflict... of which she knows nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not the only one, sir. I don't know much about the events for which I've been drafted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disarmed, but tough

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take no comfort in that, young man. In fact, I find little to take comfort in here. You are a stranger from a distant place, and I am asked to entrust the welfare of my daughter to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are not kind and patient with her, if any harm of any kind should come her way, I will have your head on a stake. Kepheus thinks he sees a smirk on Perseus' face. He puts his hand on the hilt of his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this amusing to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even a little, my lord. It's just that I myself was waylaid -- snatched also, as you say, from my happy springtime... Kepheus studies him to see if he's making jest of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been told I'm to play a part in events which serve a higher purpose... of which I'm not at all convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does a truce in the war between Men and Gods not strike you as a higher purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all respect, I have never seen a God. On my island, they're no more than a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will learn there is more to this universe than is found on your island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is supposed to be the son of a God, yet he doubts their existence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exist, young man. But if you doubt their power, I join you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassiopeia! We have agreed such talk has no place in this palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only proceed based on what I have experienced, not on a faith I do not possess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does a young person get such ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps from my adopted father, sir. I admire him greatly, and he believes in little he cannot hold in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a scholar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Your Highness, a fisherman.

dialogues.speaker: AMOUN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I know this mentor who so influences young Perseus. Amoun has silently entered the chamber. Perseus reacts in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Amoun! He hurries over to the older man, who embraces him warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porpoise... You've grown tall and strong since my departure. Perseus laughs at his old nickname and holds Amoun at arm's length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am honored to serve the King as an advisor. His Magi Strategos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From my village tutor to Magi Strategos... What a path! The King's patience is exhausted. To Cassiopeia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Andromeda? At the least, the two should meet before tomorrow's ceremony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? Is the wedding so soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding comes later. Tomorrow we will have the public announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a celebration of the treaty. A Page enters and whispers in Kepheus' ear. Kepheus is irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems our Andromeda has wandered away. Cassiopeia reacts, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps the thought of her new life has made her frantic to enjoy the vestiges of her old one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus, if you're to take the wild girl for a wife, this is a good time to start your training. Go into the city and retrieve her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will I know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is unmistakable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a stranger here. Any hints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow the lights and the sound of profane music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wilting Girl slips into the dusk like a thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wilting Girl steals down the dark, narrow alley, headed toward the outskirts of town. Suddenly, a heavy wall shoots up from the cobblestones, blocking her way. She startles, but does not stop. She goes up to the wall, turns at an angle and slides right through the stone, like a ghost. On the other side, she emerges from the stone, breathing hard. She looks around and hurries down an intersecting passageway. She's gone only a few steps, when just ahead of her, thick vines shoot out and form a dense barrier. She takes a breath and dives into the surging growth. She almost makes it through, but at the last moment, vines wrap her arms and legs, holding her prisoner. She gives up, with a sigh. We HEAR the LAUGHTER of a God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeus? Zeus' rumbling voice is held low, talking to her in an intimate way -- a beautiful sound.

dialogues.speaker: ZEUS
dialogues.text: Why do we have to play these games, my lovely girl? You know you cannot leave. The vines retract, freeing her. She rubs where they gripped her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My part is finished.

dialogues.speaker: ZEUS
dialogues.text: It has just begun. Have you forgotten your place in this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I've lost my believers, the future has become dimmer to me.

dialogues.speaker: ZEUS
dialogues.text: I still believe in you. Close your eyes and see your tomorrow. She closes her eyes and takes a deep breath. A single tear runs along her cheek. She opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too painful. I can't involve myself.

dialogues.speaker: ZEUS
dialogues.text: You you already involved. Such is fate. We cannot hide from the .trials of our future... no matter how dark the alleyway. She looks back at the Basilica with profound sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus roams, taking in the city with interest. Rich and poor mix in the crowded streets. As always, the poor have suffered the most from the conflict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus follows the MUSIC and the sound of LAUGHTER to a crowded terrace overlooking the sea. Upper class YOUNG PEOPLE are partying en masse. Perseus moves through the revelry, looking at every girl, testing his instincts. Suddenly, he stops in his tracks, looking off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromeda is dancing at the center of attention, her sheer gown enhancing her sensuality. The MUSIC ends. Andromeda laughs and tosses her curly mane. A HANDSOME YOUNG NOBLEMAN embraces her. She gives him a deep kiss, causing a sensation, then breaks away into the crush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromeda glides to the balustrade to watch the sunset. The Young Nobleman approaches, but her imperious gesture stops him cold.

dialogues.speaker: PERSEUS
dialogues.text: Very beautiful. Andromeda spins, petulant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please give me some

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight of the handsome stranger gives her pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, 'Very beautiful.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think just anyone can make intimate judgements on the royal family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant the sunset. She regards Perseus over her glistening bare shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always start a seduction with an insult? Perseus moves to the rail, very close to her, and looks at the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know nothing of seduction. I'm a simple fisherman. My home is across that water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Joppa? I was kidnapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean here, tonight. He looks over at her a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to see my future wife. Startled, Andromeda suddenly realizes who he is. A mad mix of emotions crosses her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus and Andromeda walk in moonlit gardens. She stays close, attracted to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not personal. You're not a bad-looking boy. (as Perseus laughs) I'm too young. I don't want to be married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you doing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one asked me. And now that I've met you, I don't know if I can go through with it. (off her look) It's not personal. Seeing you makes it real. I think a man should make his own decisions. I won't be the pawn of a King or a God. She looks at him with new interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since we agree, it's settled. No marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's going to be that simple. Ignoring that, she takes his arm, moving even closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean we can't be friends. Get to know each other. I want to show you something. She leads him into a tall, hedged garden maze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful in the moonlight. She hurries him quickly around one turn, then another, and another. He laughs at her excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of you. They take two more jogs and find themselves in an odd sylvan chamber. Soft plants have been stacked in what could be mistaken for a bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my special place. No one can see or hear or even find us now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose I could escape without your aid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to? When he turns back to her, she melts into his arms and gives him a long deep kiss. He's surprised, but handles it well. When she tries to continue, he slows things down, holding her at bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you not find me attractive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the most beautiful women I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, you haven't been much in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True. Maybe a lot of girls look like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to make love to your almost-wife? Maybe we'll find we're not compatible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we find we're very compat-- She stops him with another kiss. He starts to surrender to his desire, but again, he stops. Her voice is a low

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true you're a demigod?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes a face) It seems what everyone wants to believe. Her face is inches from his. She looks into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see it. (as Perseus laughs) But let's find out for sure... She kisses him yet again, pulling him toward the bed of foliage. He can no longer resist. Together they fall into the softness. He kisses her passionately as their bodies begin to move together. She breaks the kiss for only a moment, her voice husky --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm becoming a believer... They start to make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPEEDING OVER moonlit ocean TOWARD a dark castle on a cliff. WE begin to HEAR the VOICES of Tiamat and Set.

dialogues.speaker: SET
dialogues.text: Tiamat, I know this place, but I know not why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber, deserted for 25 years, is in decay, dead vermin everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: TIAMAT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In this chamber Zeus defiled the Queen Danae and begat the anointed demigod, who would facilitate this foul truce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV DESCENDING the great stairs. The skeletons of dead guards and soldiers litter the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SET
dialogues.text: Ah, the former palace of the cursed Acrisius.

dialogues.speaker: TIAMAT
dialogues.text: The King who stood against Zeus and was crushed for it, though he was not the offender. But this is not his former home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV ACROSS the stones of the hall where we first saw King Acrisius and his generals. Now, only bones and rotting things.

dialogues.speaker: TIAMAT
dialogues.text: still he dwells in rancid hate, having killed his generals and sucked their bones. We cannot break the rules of Zeus and interfere with the humans. But this poor creature can do our work and visit the would-be groom.

dialogues.speaker: SET
dialogues.text: What form of monster do you visit upon Perseus? There is an awful SOUND from the darkness of an archway.

dialogues.speaker: TIAMAT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What form, dear Set? Why this... In the half-light appears the huge, deformed changeling: KALIBOS.

dialogues.speaker: TIAMAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (to the monster) My Servant, your lonely solitude now ends... It's time to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus wakes on the bed of foliage, looks around. Andromeda is gone. He thinks, smiles. Then he remembers his situation. The smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus, in a white tunic and polished ceremonial armor, moves through the crowd of REVELERS. The grandiose room is hemmed by columns and statues. The royal family sits on the dais. Andromeda motions Perseus up beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know how to get this outfit on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to thank you for seeing me home. I was so flushed with wine I can't recall much of the evening. Perseus half smiles and turns to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me either.

dialogues.speaker: THE WILTING GIRL
dialogues.text: watches from the back of the hall. When they make eye contact, she quickly looks away.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Perseus is surprised by his feelings. Andromeda has seen her, too. He has a guilty moment and averts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what point do you plan to tell them we're not getting married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sweeping gesture) Them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the ecstatic crowd of thousands, all celebrating the union. MUSIC STOPS and the crowd begins to settle.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL HERALD, (0.5.)
dialogues.text: The Queen will speak! The room QUIETS as Cassiopeia moves front-and-center of the dais with a cup of wine, not her first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be long-winded. You all know I am a modest person, no matter my rank. Some of the crowd react silently. Andromeda watches her mother with trepidation, but not as much as Kepheus, watching from his throne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a celebration of a betrothal... (as Kepheus is on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: not the celebration of the happiness of two parents, or of our good people. Mild confusion in the hall, concern from the Royal Entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This union represents new hope for a lasting peace! That is the only cause for celebration. The crowd reacts with exclamations and applause. Amoun wills her to stop. Cassiopeia takes another drink, looks over at the Princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sweet Andromeda... grown into a fine young woman, confident and sure. Look at her! Isn't she beautiful? Her subjects agree loudly. Andromeda wishes this would end. Cassiopeia raises her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my beautiful daughter... more beautiful than all the women of Joppa. More beautiful than the Gardens of Nineveh... Kepheus is about to pull her away. She throws him a spiteful glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More beautiful than the turquoise ocean and its sublime Goddess of the Deep... Tiamat herself! My daughter is a beauty even a Goddess must envy. Amoun reacts in dismay. A distressed MURMUR roils the crowd. Andromeda goes to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gone on too long -- She stops with a look of sudden dread. The Great Hall DARKENS. The torch flames TURN BLACK. The temperature drops. The statues lining the hall shut their eyes and the doors burst open. TIAMAT, QUEEN OF THE DEEP, floats forward, parting the terrified celebrants. Perseus sees his first Olympian. Tiamat arrives at the dais. Cassiopeia drops to her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have blasphemed powers beyond understanding... You, a stupid braying goat before the unfathomable galaxies. You dare put this frivolous, scrawny slut...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: above the infinite Goddess of the Deep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiamat tears off her cloak and STANDS NAKED. Her body, made from the elements of the sea, is magnificent -- sexy and terrifying. Fantasos, the priest who proselytizes for Tiamat in the streets, is in the throng. His reaction is a mix of religious ecstasy and outright lust. The celebrants shield their eyes, but Cassiopeia can't. She crumples, aging before our eyes. Every word shakes her frame --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look upon the sublime and know your error. You'll not blink. Tell me now, mortal, how bright your preening urchin shines? No one dare look long at the Goddess. No one but Perseus. Tiamat notices Perseus... and his boldness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People of Joppa, hear me. For the sacrilege of this arrogant creature, I will loose Leviathan upon you. The people react in terror. Cassiopeia starts to faint, but Tiamat snaps her back to consciousness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not finished. Hold your gaze. (to the people) For thirty days, Joppa shall suffer the scorn of Leviathan. And on the final day, you will be wiped from the earth. (as the crowd quakes) Unless... Instant silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: unless you sacrifice that body so impertinently compared to this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- your beloved, worthless Princessa. Andromeda GASPS. Shock everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my will, Joppa. Desolation or sacrifice. Choose your penance. You can thank your... (looks at Cassiopeia) . sickly, aged Queen. Clouds of black sea ink swirl and swallow Tiamat, then implode. Tiamat is gone. Cassiopeia, palsied and withered, collapses. Kepheus and Royal Aides rush to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immense school of fish is SUDDENLY SPOOKED. An EERIE GLOW swells in the gloom -- Tiamat glides TOWARD us, stops and raises her palm. The silt SWIRLS and RIPPLES. A VAST PRIMORDIAL SHAPE SLOWLY RISES in clouds of ocean mud. It's impossible to see what this creature looks like, but it is big. We hear a deafening ROAR, which drives a SHOCKWAVE across the silt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sea bulges and a TSUNAMI rolls toward the shores of Joppa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark docks and shanties under the cliffs, populace asleep. A lone FISHERMAN unloads nets from his boat. Suddenly, the water under his boat is sucked out to sea. A deep RUMBLE shakes the ground. The fisherman is mesmerized as the horizon CLIMBS higher and higher, a WALL OF WATER. In seconds, the colossal wave breaks and falls, obliterating the boat, the docks and the low-lying shanties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassiopeia lies blank and wan. A LOW DRONE grows. Kepheus rushes to the window. And then, a deep, EARTH- SHATTERING BELLOW from the creature. The room SHUDDERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leviathan awakes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A figure passes by a window in silhouette -- Andromeda steals through the shadows toward the Throne Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromeda edges into position to see the room below.

dialogues.speaker: AMOUN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: . Leviathan -- First dweller of the deep. Hewn by Tiamat from the dark blood of the earth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A council of VICEROYS and MINISTERS gathered before Kepheus, who seems lost in thought, head down. Perseus stands off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amoun reads from a scroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . All monsters of the sea are but shadows of Leviathan the Kraken -- colossal, rapacious, and nigh indestructible. The men turn to Kepheus; when he raises his face, he looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Queen lies near death. Am I now to choose between the survival of our state... and the life of Andromeda, my only child? Amoun watches Perseus, at the fringe of the group, expectantly. But Perseus looks only perplexed, an observer.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF DEFENSE
dialogues.text: I beg you, do not even consider such a sacrifice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you tell me only what you think I wish to hear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The citizens of Joppa are fighting                for their lives. Would you have me gamble the city to save one girl? Again, Amoun looks to Perseus.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF DEFENSE
dialogues.text: You need make no such choice, Your Highness. Andromeda must.be saved, and the city too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... We need only the will to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spoke the words -- the monster is indestructible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can that be? Amoun alone takes notice: he spins toward Perseus, with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus! You had something you wanted to say to the King? All eyes turn to Perseus, who shrinks before them, self- conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No, Master Amoun. I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're 'listening'? We're talking about the precious life of your betrothed. Perseus meets his gaze, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a newcomer here. I would not presume to tell these men --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! A newcomer with a fresh perspective. Share your thoughts with the King, your future father- in-law. The ministers are puzzled by Amoun's persistence. Perseus, uncertainly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that I am young and have not seen much of the world, but it seems to me that nothing is indestructible. The Ministers react to the young man's arrogance.

dialogues.speaker: SPYROS
dialogues.text: I am far from young and have seen much of the world... and I agree with my son. Everyone turns to the new arrival: Perseus' adoptive father, Spyros. Perseus goes to embrace him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, how did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this boy's father was a God. How does a stranger walk unmolested into the Throne Room of the King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent for him, Lord. This good man raised Perseus from infancy. He will help him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help him with what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With whatever is needed... Perseus approaches the King. Surprising himself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will help me destroy Leviathan. Spyros does a double-take, then swallows: "Yeah, okay, sure."

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE BALCONY
dialogues.text: Andromeda reacts, falling in love with Perseus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how? Perseus has no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, we can seek the counsel of the Norn Sisters of Skolothia. They know the hidden ways of the                       Gods. If Leviathan can be slain, they'll know how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have thirty days to find its weakness.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR
dialogues.text: Twenty-nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashes him a look) We'll leave tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what army? I dare not weaken                      our forces when the city is about                      to be besieged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertain, glances

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Give us a map.                                    Amoun laughs. When some of the others join in, the   King gives them a look that stops them dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My King, with your permission... The King assents, seemingly lost. Amoun speaks to Perseus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a map and much more. I'll go with you and bring a small band of comrades to help you on your mission. We can leave at first light. (to his Aide) Diokles, the map. The men move to the work area, where the Aide selects a map from dozens. Something catches Perseus' eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andromeda, up in the balcony, has made herself visible only to him. She silently mouths these words -- "Thank... you."

dialogues.speaker: AT THE MAP
dialogues.text: which has been hung for all to see, Amoun uses a pointer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We head north on the Via Dahlia. If we can make it to the Disputed Territories... MOVE IN ON the tip of Amoun's pointer on the

dialogues.speaker: AMOUN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: . we'll join the Cleon desert legion, the most formidable unit in all the army... With their escort, we can safely reach our destination in Skolothia, which lies to the east... We DISSOLVE THROUGH the map and pointer, which remain LIGHTLY SUPERIMPOSED over the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC SWELLS as we see THE FULL EXPEDITION on horseback, on the main road north. As they come over a rise, Amoun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, two fearsome Mongols, MONGKE and TAMBURLANE.

dialogues.speaker: AMOUN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Our guides will be Mongke and Tamburlane, father and son monster hunters from the Kingdom of the Iron Horde. Next, THE PRAETORIAN GUARD, commanded by a square-jawed old soldier, DRACO. His men, in heavy armor: KOSMO, Draco's lieutenant, and the soldiers ABAS, ICOS, THAD, BOREAS, KRIKOR, and POLLUC.

dialogues.speaker: AMOUN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Our escort will be a detachment of the Praetorian Guard, led by Commander Draco -- the staunchest security force in Joppa. Next, on a stunning pale horse, a pale rider -- the Wilting Girl.

dialogues.speaker: PERSEUS
dialogues.text: Why do we bring the Earth Goddess into this danger?

dialogues.speaker: AMOUN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I thank the stars we have her. Besides, she takes her orders from an authority much greater than I. Next, Spyros; horseback riding is not one of his many skills. Behind him, Perseus and Amoun ride talking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amoun, it seems an odd coincidence you came into my life as tutor, so long ago, and now, once again you instruct me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter what you believe, Porpoise, some things are fated. I've been looking forward to this journey for a long, long time. He spurs his horse, riding ahead. Spyros drops back beside Perseus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would have thought we'd be on a journey like this? Two simple fishermen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I've dragged you into real danger, Father, when I have little idea of what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living at the mercy of the sea so long has convinced me some adventures are unexpected and some dangers unavoidable. It's all in your attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's our attitude about destroying Leviathan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kraken is just another big fish. Perseus smiles, but is not as sanguine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiamat's Palace-Galleon is bigger than anything man can construct. Tiamat is at the prow of the vessel, using all her godly power to STIR THE ELEMENTS. With great effort, she sends a hurricane down on Joppa. Set the Void approaches the prow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The demigod and his retinue are joined. They march for the counsel of the Norn Sisters, to seek the frailty of my Leviathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sisters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I beseech you, track the expedition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To plainly thwart them would betray our intentions and draw the wrath of Zeus and the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, we cannot have. I merely suggest that the road to Skolothia is hazardous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take your meaning. And your loyal brute, he is fixed upon the hunt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear not, he is about and he will do his share of damage. Set leaves. Tiamat resumes stirring the storm clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiamat's storm is pounding Joppa. LIGHTNING stabs through the dark clouds. RAIN POUNDS the tiles outside Andromeda's lavish bedroom. Peshet glides to Andromeda, who's wide awake, red-eyed, distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must sleep. (off no reaction) Princessat You must take care of yourself. A CRACK OF THUNDER. Andromeda looks over at her, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was ready to sacrifice me to the monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that is not so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it. I heard the words. My loving father, his beloved child. Only Perseus stayed his decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you know the worst part, Peshet? He was right. Peshet's feline eyes widen. More LIGHTNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city is besieged, the people suffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of me, because he did not offer me up. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to sleep, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiping her eyes) Sleep? Sleep will come soon enough for me, faithful one. In one month... at the latest. The palace shakes with the ROLLING THUNDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of that same DISTANT THUNDER as the Expedition follows the road. To the south behind them, LIGHTNING FLASHES over faraway Joppa. SUPERIMPOSE: THE VIA DAHLIA, NORTH OF JOPPA...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus and the Wilting Girl ride side by side. Perseus looks back at the distant storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joppa is pummelled by the Dark Goddess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will not stop. Tiamat knows no mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moonlight illuminates a crumbling, limestone arch on which time-worn letters read: "VIA DAHLIA."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By what name may mortals call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do your worshippers pray to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps that is why they are falling in number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wilting Girl flinches, and Perseus feels guilty about his jest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to call you something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since we're naming you on this road, what about 'Via Dahlia'? She gives him a sharp look. Is he mocking her? He's defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a pretty name. Wait, better yet -- 'Vidalia'? How's that... 'Vidalia'? That's more than pretty, beautiful really, just as you are. She is pleased, self-conscious, concentrating on the road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like it? (as she murmurs) What's that? I missed it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just loud enough to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not object. She picks up the pace, moving her horse a little ahead. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've camped for the night in a clearing. A fire burns, food cooks. Mongke and Tamburlane emerge from the woods with armfuls of timber and kindling. Draco glances up from striking his flintstone. Gruffly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More. The Mongols stare -- either not comprehending or ready to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must last all night. Get some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, I'll get some, too. Perseus and Abas head off into the woods in different directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus hacks branches and picks up deadwood. He slashes at a tree -- TING! Under the vines is a stone column. He climbs mossy steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ruins of a public bath, its marble pool fed by a stream. Perseus sees Vidalia on the far side, her back turned. Perseus freezes as she drops her garment. He peers through the vines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leaves offer tantalizing cover to her naked body. She dives in with a quiet SPLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now is when an honorable man would turn around and walk away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . but they say I am not really a man. Vidalia surfaces and drifts on her back, looking sadly into the sky. Perseus fixates on the sadness in her eyes. His expression changes, and the tenor of this stolen vigil is altered. RAINDROPS fall as the SKY OPENS and a CLOUDBURST pelts the pool. Vidalia opens her lips to taste the rain and smiles. LIGHTNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus' HEART POUNDS in his ears as he watches. KRA- KOOM! The ROLLING THUNDER hits exactly on his heartbeat -- BOOM, BOOM, BOOM! Vidalia instantly knows he is nearby. She looks around quickly and huddles in the water. Perseus retreats. After a few yards, he stops, face flushed with the awareness of a whole new dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vidalia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abas uses his sword to HACK at dried wood. He bends to pick up a branch when he HEARS the CRACK of wood. He whirls, sword at ready. But there is nothing there. Embarrassed, he picks up the firewood. Now he HEARS something unidentifiable -- is that BREATHING? Spooked, he turns to head back to camp -- A DARK FIGURE is standing behind him, larger than a man, grotesquely misshapen. Abas raises his sword, but a twisted PAW swats it away with a ROAR. Abas tries to raise the sword again and realizes his arm is gone. He looks up in horror as the Creature envelops him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a few streaks of sunlight penetrate the canopy of tall cedars. SUPERIMPOSE: THE CEDAR FOREST OF THE ILLYRIAN BORDER...

dialogues.speaker: DAYS REMAINING
dialogues.text: Here slumbers an enormous hybrid creature with human features and a leathery, scaled hide -- HUMBABA. Suddenly, Set the Void appears. The evil God strokes the sleeping monster's head, then reaches inside Humbaba's skull. The animal goes stiff; its leg twitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear me, my pet. Let my instructions be seared to your primal mind as natural law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monster's eyes shoot open; its pupils shrink to pinpoints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are starving. Your gut says you'll soon perish. No earthly meat will still that hunger. What you need, what you ache for, is the flesh of... a demigod!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearby, the Expedition (minus Abas) rests. Not here: Perseus, Draco, Icos, and Boreas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A herd of winged horses, PEGASSI, graze. Draco, Boreas, Icos and Perseus  -- thrilled -- hide in a thicket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pegassi, stallions of the Gods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus. How long do you think you could stay on one of those? Icos and Boreas exchange a sly look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't goad the boy, Icos. No Man can ride a Pegasus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did not Bellerophon tame the Great White Pegasus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. But he was a                   demigod...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then this will be a good way to find out just what I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, rogues. One of our own has disappeared without a trace and all you can think is to cause mischief. What if Perseus is bucked to his death from a thousand feet up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Commander, the boy won't even get on its back. With a "watch this" grin, Perseus rises. Draco pulls him back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do this. If we go back to camp right now, we can avoid trouble and keep our goal in sight. A true leader will not be distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the leader, Draco, Amoun is. I'm too young to start avoiding trouble. Perseus jumps up and approaches a roan Pegasus, speaking soothingly. It WHINNIES and threshes its wings, buffeting Perseus with gusts. The Pegasus rears up, and leaps over Perseus' head. It lands behind him, bucks its hind legs, and kicks Perseus face-first into the dirt. Icos and Boreas are laughing, but when Draco gives them a dark look, Boreas jumps up, sobered, and heads into the clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll collect him right now, Commander. Suddenly, Humbaba erupts from the thicket with a HOWL. The Pegassi take flight, but the Humbaba grabs one and swallows it whole. Humbaba turns and SNIFFS the air, homing in on Perseus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus, get out of there! Icos, fetch the others. Icos bolts. Draco and Boreas leap into the clearing with swords drawn to draw the monster's attention. Perseus does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to run, boy. You'll make things worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing the ROARS, the Expedition is already up. Icos arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Humbaba! Mongke and Tamburlane fly into the woods; the others follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reinforcements arrive to see Humbaba pin Boreas with its talons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boreas! Draco hacks at the monster's leg, to no avail. it rips off Boreas' head and swallows his body. Perseus CRIES OUT and leaps at the creature, sword swinging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Perseus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back! Vidalia spins her shepherd's sling to pitch lead sling- bullets. Spyros leaps between Perseus and the monster and thrusts his weapon -- a VICIOUS-LOOKING HARPOON/BOAT HOOK. Tamburlane hoists an ancient BAZOOKA. Mongke lights the fuse and backs away. KA-BOOM! The weapon belches fire and metal. The Humbaba staggers from the shot, but lunges and swallows Mongke whole. Spyros sinks his harpoon in one leg, but has it ripped from his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A delusion is planted in its mind. It thinks it's starving and it wants to feed on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Humbaba's eyes bulge with surprise as a saber pierces its nose. From inside, Mongke pries open the beast's mouth with his saber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't reverse the powerful curse. But if the monster's hungry, I can feed it. Vidalia raises her arms and shuts her eyes. A cyclone of CAWING RAVENS descends from the sky and dives straight into the monster's mouth. As the Humbaba tries to shake them away, Mongke is thrown clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! The belly! Slash the belly! Draco moves to do that when Perseus leaps forward, lunges and sweeps his blade up Humbaba's belly at the same moment Draco sweeps down. The two blades barely miss each other, opening a huge X in the belly. The others are shocked and impressed by Perseus. Steaming purple entrails spill over Perseus and Draco. HUMBABA CRASHES TO THE GROUND. The flock of ravens, liberated from Humbaba's gut, shake the viscera from their feathers and take flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseus, somber, washes the creature's guts from his arms and legs. He turns to find Vidalia standing above him, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should cast a spell upon you and leave you forever a stone upon this stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't beckon the Humbaba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did, with your childish recklessness, and Boreas has paid the price! Perseus, already rife with guilt, is stung by the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
